page.title: 09HILL FARMING AROUND MENSTRIE
page.content: The hills around Menstrie take up more than a third of our area, they are mainly used for sheep farming and rough grazing. In the winter the sheep are taken down into pens. In our area the lambing comes late in Spring. And before the lambing season the gorse is burnt to prevent the lambs from being caught in the spiny branches. Some sheep each year are killed by falling down gulleys or slipping down the almost sheer south side of the hills. Every few weeks the sheperds move the sheep to a new grazing pasture. The fleeces of the sheep are sent to the Wool Marketing Board. Many of the sheperds live on small holdings situated on the lower faces of the hills. The peaks of the hills are too rocky to be of use to farmers.
